title: How many people in the US will have received one or more doses of a COVID-19 vaccine as of 31 May 2021, according to the CDC?
preds: I think this is going to be very close after all the data comes in, but leaning toward below 170. The last fully reported day is May 25 at 166.2, 6 days left at 600k puts it just below 170.

With today's reporting, and seeing 0.63M/day added for the past week and falling, I don't see how it will be possible to get to 170M. It will be close, but I'm certain it will be under 170M. If 0.63M/day are added for the next 4 days (inc. 3 for back reporting), we'll get to 170.25M. But I just don't see how the number added per day won't fall, both because of the continuing trend and because of the holiday weekend. Yesterday, the projection at yesterday's rate added/week without continued decline was 170.51M; today's projection without continued decline is 170.25M. Tomorrow's projection without continued decline will likely be ~170.0M, with even greater declines from the holiday yet to show up. I think the final number will be closer to 169.0M than to 170.0M. Update 6/1: Today's number is 168.49M. 0.76M added in the past day. (Approximately) 2 more days of back reporting left. 168.49M + 0.76M * 2 = 170.01M. With continuing decline, the total will be just under 170M. Update 6:3: Today's total is 169.09M, which will be close to the final total. It's <170M.

There are currently approximately 160 million people with 1 dose or more, and the rate is begging to slow down plateau. Most people who want the vaccine have now had it, and most people who remain unvaccinated either don’t want it or are too young. It’s very unlikely that by the end of this month we will see a huge jump in number of vaccines.

Unpredictable...despite Memorial Day, I think 170m+ is a tiny bit more likely. 
It may remain suspenseful until data accession on June 14 – @belikewater my gut feeling is that it will jump over 170m on June 13 …

Today at 167.73M. 0.57M added in the past day. 0.77M added the day before. 4.42M added in the past week, or 0.63M/day. 4 days left in forecast (inc. 3 for back reporting). 167.73M + 4*0.63M = 170.25M. And, there will likely be fewer vaccines given over Memorial Day weekend, both because doses given are declining and because fewer people will likely get vaccinated over the holiday, although any extra decline won't fully show up in reporting until June 2. My current best guess is that the final number will be between 169.0M and 170.0M.

Gonna be close but I'm hedging that the lag will bring it over the top. Though my three most recent judgements have all said just under 170M. And I did poorly on a similar question. Caveat: I think it's important not to use the most recent available figures because they have not "matured." So counterintuitively, despite it being further in the past, you will get a more reliable prediction (assumption to this particular question).

Today at 167.16M. 0.77M added in the past day, continuing the decline. 4.69M added in the past week, or 0.67M/day. 5 days left in forecast (inc. 3 for back reporting). 167.16M + 5*0.67M = 170.51M. And, there will likely be fewer vaccines given over Memorial Day weekend, both because doses given are declining and because fewer people will likely get vaccinated over the holiday. However, to what extent fewer people get vaccinated over the holiday won't be known until the forecast is closed, as the full extent doesn't show up for 2 days, based on previous holidays. I will guess that maybe 0.6M to 0.8M fewer people than expected will be vaccinated this long weekend. Even if 0.5M fewer than expected don't get vaccinated, just from the daily decline alone, I think the final number will probably go <170M. My current best guess is that the final number will be between 169.0M and 170.0M.
@CJH, I don't think it's likely that the forecast will end up >170M.

166.3m plus 1m backlog = 167.3m
3 days reporting left.  Current rate just under 800k
Will be close to 170m threshold.  
It all hinges on the accuracy of my assumption on backlog reporting!
Looks like the final count for May 31st will be near 170M so it's hard to pick a bin.
Looking close, though 170 favored because of data lag. We'll see.
On the edge on this one but I think @CJH, @timothy_chan, and @gregorcb has the right idea here, among others who are forecasting the 170 bin. @TMelvin was vying the 170 bin for a while, too.

Today's reported doses were ~0.6M lower than last week's on the same day. Only 0.6M added today to the total for this forecast, and this is one of the higher 4 reporting days of the week. Either people are already getting ready for Memorial Day weekend, or the age 12-15 bump is over. Either way, I would sincerely doubt that the next 4 days are going to be much higher than today and will likely be lower. 165.7M as of 5/27. Average of 0.79M/day added in the past week. As of yesterday, 0.84M/day. The day before, 0.86M/day. 4 days ago, 0.88M/day. 6 days ago, 0.8M/day, 0.7M/day the week before that. 165.7M + 7 days (inc. 3 back reporting days) * 0.79M/day (allowing only a slight decline) = 171.2. Without 3 Memorial Day weekend days, we get to 165.7M + 4 * 0.79M = 168.9M. It would seem likely that 1.1M people could be added over the 3 Memorial Day weekend days, but it's not clear to me whether the average/day won't fall low enough to get to <170M.  Would need to add an average of <0.61M/day to get to <170M. Today should have been a "high" day but was at 0.6M. Still too close to call, but it's looking to me like the lower bin is more likely after all. Update 5/28: today at 166.4M. 0.7M added in the past day. See what happens tomorrow.
Update 5/29: today at 167.16M. 0.77M added in the past day. 4.69M added in the past week, or 0.67M/day. 5 days left in forecast (inc. 3 for back reporting). 167.16M + 5*0.67M = 170.51M. And, there will likely be fewer vaccines given over Memorial Day weekend. Time to update.

So confused only by trying to go from on webpage and back to answer questions that are very similar in wording maybe a number associated with questions would make easier to track as I have about 50 open questions now 
Thanks for the help as I lost my way on this group of questions

I'm assuming the daily vaccination rate will continue to decrease and we won't see more than 170M vaccinated people. This also assumes that there won't be a correction due to reporting error (Though, I didn't do the research about the base rate for such a correction).

165.1m plus 1m backlog = 166.1m
5 reporting days to go
170m threshold = 3.9m = 0.78m per day
Current rate =0.8m per day It’s going to be close to 170m. It all depends on whether my 1m backlog added is too low.  The rate could go either way.

165.1M as of 5/26. Average of 0.84M/day added in the past week. As of yesterday, 0.86M/day. 3 days ago, 0.88M/day. 5 days ago, 0.8M/day, 0.7M/day the week before that. The number of doses reported today represents a decline over the same day last week and continues a downward trend that has been only slightly interrupted by vaccinating children ages 12 to 15. 165.1M + 8 days (inc. 3 back reporting days) * 0.82M/day (allowing only a slight decline) = 171.5. Without 3 Memorial Day weekend days, we get to 165.1M + 5 * 0.82M = 169.2M. It would seem likely that 0.8M people could be added over the 3 Memorial Day weekend days, but it's not certain whether the average/day won't fall lower than 0.8M. It's getting too close to call.

Average of 0.86M/day added in the past week. As of 2 days ago, 0.88M/day. As of 4 days ago, 0.8M/day, and 0.7M/day the week before that. 6 days left in forecast + 3 for back reporting. 164.4M (total as of 5/25) + 9 * 0.86M/day = 172.1M, identical to my forecast 2 days ago. Again, the question is what will happen on Memorial Day weekend. Suppose Wed. through Friday add 0.86M/day, and that the 3 back reporting days add 0.8M/day. That brings us to 169.4M. So Memorial Day weekend vaccination rates would have to be almost zero to stay under 170M. So I think it's time to update, @CJH. Many in the crowd don't add 3 back reporting days; we saw this in the forecasts in the last round that were close to a forecast bin limit. I wonder whether the crowd so strongly favors <170M in part because of this. But it's clear today (and I should have realized before) that >170M is very likely. It's still possible that vaccination rates could fall off over the next 3 days, so this should be watched closely.
Update: I adjusted to 45%/55% because of the uncertainty over declining rates over the next few days. And I see your forecast isn't too different from that!
current pace plus today's number is 173 million
It's looking like the total will be very close to 170M. I'm assuming there will be declining participation now that the initial spike of 12-16 year olds is over.
I think >170M would likely be reached if Memorial Day weekend weren't coming up.

0.88M/day added in the past week. A lot of kids must be getting vaccinated. As of 2 days ago, 0.8M/day. 0.7M/day added the week before that. Say, 0.8M/day more for the rest of the forecast. 8 more days left in forecast + 3 for back reporting. 163.31M as of 5/23 + 0.8M/day * 11 days = 172.1M. Would need to stay under an average of 0.61M/day to stay under 170M at this point. When will the numbers start falling again?

0.8M/day added in the past week. 0.7M/day added the week before that. 11 more days left in forecast + 3 for back reporting. 160.2M as of 5/20 + 0.8M*14 = 171.4M. 160.2M + 0.7M*14 = 170.0M. Will the numbers start falling again?

Total vaccines to date; 279,397,250 as of today  Thursday, May 20, 2021.
https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/index.html
Daily numbers are down, and hesitancy (including fears of having to pay!) are not going to make a reversal easier.
Currently at 158,365,411 with 12 days to go.
After a small bump from children ages 12 to 15 getting vaccinated, the decline in the average daily vaccination rate continues apace.
First dose rate has been declining. Only way it goes up is new demographics start receiving vaccines.
Oops. This forecast is a mistake. Updating shortly.

153.5m plus 1.5m for backlog = 155m
15m in 19 days for 170m = 790k per day
Average is at 700kish per day now.  Everyday below 790k makes it harder to get to 170m.

Extrapolating from 05. May : Total people with at least one dose :  
05 May: 151.35 M ;
04 May: 150.63 M
-> Difference: 0.72 M 0.72 M/Day * 25 Days + 151.35 M = 169.35 M - But the trend seems to slow down.
- It seems to become harder to find people willing to be vaccinated
- But Children could accelerate it again (see @Emking)  [ How big is the group of children 12-16 year old, and how many of them could be vaccinated until end of the question? ]
Ages 12–17: 25.2 M  (https://www.childstats.gov/AMERICASCHILDREN/tables/pop1.asp)
Approximately 15 % of the adult population was vaccinated in the last 30 days, so 2 M children could receive a dose in the next two weeks.
[But can this compensate the downward trend?]
Currently I would say a light "no" (so the numbers stay under 170 M).
Moving away from the lowest tranche as the downward trend may end next week with 12-16 year old inclusion.

NPR has numbers going up:
https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2021/01/28/960901166/how-is-the-covid-19-vaccination-campaign-going-in-your-state I believe people are reading far too much in the slowdown - a lot more people are hesitant than anti-vax, and far more just need easier access. As there is more availability for walk-ins, I expect numbers will go up. Another element changing the situation is 12-15 year olds, most of whom are likely looking forward to vaccines to get back to normalcy. Maybe a lot of assumptions about their hesitancy are projection? I get there's some hesitancy, especially after they were told they weren't affected, but they're a pretty smart generation, and they are sharing stories of peers that still have symptoms months later. 
https://labblog.uofmhealth.org/rounds/most-young-people-eager-for-covid-19-vaccine-poll-shows

152.1m plus 1.5m for backlog reporting = 153.6m
21 days to go
Threshold
170m = 780k per day
Current average 775k and will drop more as last couple of fully reported days are lower than equivalent of the week before.  
It’s getting hard to get over the 170m.

149m as of May 2 with a 7d rolling avg of 625k and dropping rather fast. As mentioned, 12-15 year olds becoming eligible will increase the available supply of arms to jab. Even maintaining the current pace would only get to 166.5m, so I largely go with the consensus view that we won't exceed 170m this month.
Extremizing the opinion of the crowd here.

Updating. Starting probably early next week, kids age 12 to 15 will be eligible. There are ~16.8M (estimate) in this age group. Recent surveys have said that ~29% of parents are eager to have their kids vaccinated as soon as they're eligible. 16.8M * 0.3 = 5M, so perhaps the total this month will be boosted by ~5M children.
https://www.npr.org/sections/coronavirus-live-updates/2021/05/04/993519402/pfizer-says-fda-will-soon-authorize-covid-19-vaccine-for-12-15-age-group
https://www.nytimes.com/2021/05/06/health/vaccine-children.html However, also in the 2nd link above is that 9% of US adults haven't yet gotten the vaccine but plan to do so. Let's say the age 16+ eligible population is ~264M; 0.09 * 264M = 23.8M. Of course, not everyone who says they plan to get vaccinated will do so or will do so immediately. So, adding 23.8M to the current total would likely be an upper limit. Moreover, the survey that obtained that figure was conducted between April 15 and 29. By April 15, 125.8M people had been reported to have received at least one dose, and by April 29, 143.8M had. So, likely no more than 143.8M + 23.8M = 167.6M, and probably closer to a max of (125.8M + 143.8M)/2 + 23.8M = 158.6M. So, the maximum number of people who will likely get vaccinated in the near-ish future is probably 158.6M to 167.6M (age 16+) + 5M (age 12-15) = 163.6M to 172.6M. I suspect the true near-term max is closer to 164M even with kids. Update 5/8: 0.73M/day added in past week. Taking that as a maximum, with 26 more forecast days (including 3 days for back reporting, we get to 151.3M (May 8 total) + 0.73M * 26 = 170.28. But we'll be adding much less than that soon, except for kids. Doses administered are falling by 0.38M/day/week.

148.5m today.  Add 2m for backlog reporting = 150.8m
25 days to go
Thresholds:
170m = 770k per day
180m = 1.15m per day
190m = 1.6m per day Current rate = 900k per day and dropping
Vaccinations at 40pc and question of limits being reached.
Was looking around to see reasons why rates are dropping so fast and found these 
https://www.ft.com/video/527bb88a-96bd-4112-8dd9-bb3747bde7fd
https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/covid-19-survey-36-of-adults-in-the-us-unsure-about-vaccine-protection#Significant-barriers-to-vaccination
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-05-04/is-u-s-vaccination-slowing-down-in-most-states-yes Some interesting point.  The most easily or keen to be vaccinated have been done.  Clarity on who is eligible when seems poor and inconsistent.  Large vaccination centres suggest few and far between so travel needed to access (in comparison to uk which is numerous and local).  There also seems to be some supply issues versus demand, and then there is the question of reduction in confidence after the J&J pause.  Even if that’s not a real problem, has the perception caused lower keenness?
The Bloomberg article also talks about warmer weather (not here though), being able to be outside and spring summer suppression reducing perception of urgency. Given all these things it looks more like the number of vaccinations will continue to drop and could easily get below the level for 170m.

Average daily doses administered are decreasing by ~0.4M/day/week. If one projects that decline linearly out to May 31, only about 85k people/day would be receiving vaccines. However, children age 12-15 will be eligible to take the vaccine starting as early as next week. That will add a pool of almost 17M people eligible to take the vaccine, of which up to ~70% or ~12M may get the vaccine. On the other hand, vaccine hesitancy is strongest among young adults. 148.6M to date. 6.1M more people received at least one vaccine dose in the past week, or 0.87M/day. Forecasting that outward 29 days gets to 174M. But the reality will not be linear. Upshot: I think adult vaccinations are winding down rapidly. Children may provide a boost of 5M to 12M at most in the forecast period. My guess is that somewhere in the ballpark of 14M adults will be added and ~4M to 7M children will be added, for a total of 149M + 14M + 6M = 169M, right on the line between bins. I'll weight the lower category higher, because adult vaccination might fall off much faster, and fewer children than that may get vaccinated because the perceived risk to children is low (despite long Covid).

148.8m today.  Add 2m for backlog reporting = 150.8m
25 days to go
Thresholds:
170m = 790k per day
180m = 1.15m per day
190m = 1.6m per day Current rate = 900k per day and dropping
Vaccinations at 40pc and question of limits being reached.
Range 170 to 180m with low possibility of dropping below 170m.  Can’t see rate increasing fast enough to get past 180m

If looking at adults alone 170 million would be about 68% of the eligible population. Based on polls I'm skeptical it gets close to that high in the coming month. There are a lot of people who are "wait and see" on the polls, and while some of them may be convinced I think that'll be a long term process over the summer, maybe convincing half or so of those people. According to the poll linked below 62% of people have gotten it or will get it ASAP. But if Pfizer opens up 12 to 16 year olds for vaccination which may happen in the next week or two that could increase vaccination rates. According to the second link there are around 25 million kids ages 12 to 17. If half of those get it that could add around 12 million vaccinations in the long term, and maybe the optimistic case is half of those get their first dose this month. Overall I think the most optimistic case possible would be doing a million new vaccinations a day, which would put it at 180 million. Poll: https://www.kff.org/coronavirus-covid-19/dashboard/kff-covid-19-vaccine-monitor-dashboard/ Ages 12-17: https://www.statista.com/statistics/457786/number-of-children-in-the-us-by-age/
